reviews.author: @interview-signal

reviews.content:
When I first saw the advertisements for the F1 movie I knew I had to watch it. I personally am not too into the sport, but the immersive visuals hooked me. At the start, you are introduced to Sonny Hayes, a man whose career almost ended in a brutal crash. Throughout the entire movie, this crash seems to be haunting him, even being the reason as to why he left the sport in the first place. He‚Äôs portrayed by Brad Pitt, who I know mostly for his roles as David Mills on Se7en and Tyler Durden on Fight Club. A couple months before I saw the F1 movie, I saw Se7en so I already had high expectations for the F1 movie. Anyway, he goes on to win the 24 Hours of Daytona and meets with his former teammate and close friend, Ruben Cervantes. His friend recruits him into his currently failing team known as APXGP, where he meets Joshua Pearce, a young rising star in the F1 scene. Pearce is played by Damson Idris, a person widely known for their role as Franklin Saint on Snowfall. Throughout the entire story, these two are our main characters. 
	Sonny Hayes' whole role in the entire movie is to be a mentor for Pearce. And that‚Äôs exactly what he does. One thing that I loved about Sonny was his calmness compared to Joshua. While Joshua is kind of like a hot head, Hayes keeps his cool in almost every situation. They are essentially the opposites of each other. Also, the evolution of their relationship is something that I thought was great. They begin with having a sort of rivalry and high egos; though, most of this is just Joshua. Thus, as the story progresses more, Joshua starts to kind of understand Hayes and they both create a mutual respect for each other and think of the team first rather than their own selves. In the end, one of the main points of the movie is their bond and how it grows.
	Moving on from the characters, the movie‚Äôs visuals are stunning. The movie shows the competitiveness within F1 and helps viewers understand what truly happens on the track. One thing I was surprised to find out about this was that some scenes were actually shot during the Grand-Prix‚Äôs. Also, the movie shows realistic racing, but this was something I expected since Lewis Hamilton was one of the producers of the movie. In my opinion, this is something that fits both casual movie watchers, and fans of F1. 
In conclusion, I think this is something that is worth watching. The characters are great, and so are the visuals. I can‚Äôt say much except to just tell you to watch it. It‚Äôs a great movie which can leave you with an interest in F1. There are many great things about this movie that I didn‚Äôt mention like the importance of Haye‚Äôs deck of cards. It‚Äôs a movie that will have you wondering about the next adventure of Hayes.

reviews.content:
Not being a particular Formula 1 fan, I didn't focus on the aesthetic boldness of director Joseph Kosinski. So I set aside any comparisons with the harsh realities of this world.
And I'm glad I did, because I loved this blockbuster. Admittedly, the storyline is somewhat farcical, with the sixty-year-old man called in to save a team in total decline. It's a bit like Jackie Stewart, having become a team manager, calling Jacky Ickx back in 2000 to do battle with Schumacher and H√§kkinen.
But it's cinema, so it doesn't matter, right? Especially since the racing scenes are impressive. I didn't notice the time passing, and the film still lasts 2 hours and 35 minutes. And then there's the music by Hans Zimmer, of course.
I honestly had a good laugh. Javier Bardem is exquisite as usual, Damson Idris has a beautiful smile, little Kerry Condon is delicious as can be and Brad Pitt is still as cool as ever... "Who said anything about safe ?" üòâ

reviews.content: A romantic story unfolds between a striking man and a woman lonely in heart. The narrative juxtaposes a young, inexperienced racer with a seasoned veteran, highlighting the contrasting appeal of a fair-skinned and a dark-skinned driver. Set in an authentic motorsport location, the film boasts impressive cinematography and features appearances by real-life Formula 1 legends. With precise and polished editing‚Äîreminiscent of assembling the finest ingredients‚Äîit delivers a satisfying cinematic experience. Though it becomes evident that the script is from classic formulas, its allure remains undiminished.

reviews.content: My previous criticism of F1  stemmed from my shallow understanding. The plot design of the film is actually realistic, reliable, and visionary. APXGP clearly has a real-world prototype, and they have proven that earning points and even reaching the podium within half a season is not impossible. All of this undoubtedly reveals my ignorance. reviews.content: Time has proven that Robert Kubica's haters (especially those damn British buffoons) were wrong. Robert won the WRC2 championship in his first year of racing, driving a non-factory rally car! He also competed in the WRC, driving a DIY car, setting faster times on special stages than Loeb or Ogier, like the Monte Carlo Rally! If only Robert had been given a chance and hadn't joined a team as crappy as the then-Williams under Clair's disastrous leadership, Robert could have easily scored consistently in the top ten, even top five. With such a weak car, worse than the media darling and anointed George Russell, Robert still did his best, and his true class showed at the German Grand Prix at Hockenheim, where he finished 10th, in a race that was tested by heavy rain, equaling the drivers' skills and technological advantage of the leading teams.  Just look at how George (whom I like) has progressed in his sporting career, currently driving a better car in a top team. Robert was just as good at Williams ‚Äì note: With One Hand! In short, such a film could easily be made based on a script written by life itself, but the story is unfinished ‚Äì mainly due to the F1 Williams Racing Team, money, and a lack of vision among influential figures.

reviews.content:
This movie really benefits from the fact it succeeds in its primary job as a movie, which is to entertain. I‚Äôve seen so many movies that try to do so much with the plot that it gets in the way of being something to enjoy. F1 uses a generic plot because the plot is actually a platform to deliver some of the best cinematography and sound design work I‚Äôve ever seen in a movie this year.

As an F1 fan, seeing this movie take place in actual race venues with genuine F1 fans (since they followed the F1 calendar to film during Grand Prix events) made the movie‚Äôs setting feel much more genuine even though the story is obviously fictional. The race sequences were amazing, with the actors driving alongside actual F1 racing drivers in their cars.

I think much of the criticism comes from a vocal minority of F1 fans and pundits who believe F1 is ‚Äúabove being portrayed by Hollywood,‚Äù which I think is quite ironic given that F1 is quite literally seen as a circus by those who exist outside of that bubble.

I actually think F1 could be a legitimate Oscar contender for some of the technical categories, and even best original song. We‚Äôll have to see, but in general I agree that this was a true summer blockbuster.

reviews.content:
I watched it 2 times. The first time was about me looking for a fun action movie. The second time, was about me doing a team-building activity. I treated my research staff to this movie because I wanted them to understand the value of working as a team.

While the drivers are the ones front and center, the movie shows how it actually takes an entire team to win the races. No role is too small or insignificant. From the team owner singing the checks, to the drivers, the Engineer, Mechanics, Coaches, Analysts behind a keyboard, even to that person who is supposed to properly unscrew a tire had an indispensable role. I love how the movie showed just that. 

Everybody in the team was short of something. The lead driver was talented but was an ego-maniac. The older driver is experienced, but is physically and psychologically scarred. The team owner is losing money, the engineer is inexperienced, the mechanics lack confidence under pressure, but when they all come together they manage to nullify each others weaknesses. 

We now also adopt the mantra "Slow is smooth, and smooth is fast",

This movie understands that their core demo will be the people who know the difference, and it goes to great efforts to not make us feel insulted by hand-having.  A layperson won't recognize that they used the real F-14 HUD and switches in Top Gun Maverick, but the people who obsess over F-14s will.  Same deal here.

reviews.content: I really enjoyed this modern take on the old westerns where a mysterious gunslinger rides into town and is called upon to save the day, passing along their wisdom and maybe learning a little themselves, then ride off alone into the sunset after emerging victorious. Apart from the absence of all the political baggage and rejection of previous generations that has become the norm for the last however many years, it also subverts expectations in a good way for once by avoiding a few tropes that, while not bad necessarily, have been done in a slew of other movies. There's the scene, for example, where JP's friend and manager wants him to go out partying and networking again but JP has matured and realized that it's time to end that part of his life and tells his friend so in coded language. His friend pauses for a few beats and you wonder if this will be another 'sometimes those around you can't grow with you' moment before he surprises by accepting the change without drama. It's a nice moment that acknowledges that sometimes our better angels can win out, as is the case with Ruben who you might expect (rich guy fighting a cut throat political battle with reputation and millions of dollars on the line) would selfishly put his need for a win ahead of Sonny's health but instead shows that his concern and love for his friend is genuine and more important to him than winning or money. The story comes together nicely with plenty of exciting action and twists that keep you on your toes and ends on a positive note that feels true to the characters as they've been portrayed. It's not the greatest movie ever made, but it's fun and well constructed, has heart and, I think, holds up to repeat viewings which has been pretty rare of late.

reviews.content:
Admittedly haven't seen it yet, but I get the feeling that this is what happens when you put people on the team based on their demonstrated aptitude as opposed to bullshit characteristics that don't contribute meaningfully to the task of making a movie. Kosinski, Bruckheimer, Hamilton. Get the people who are good at doing the thing to do the thing you want done. No need to complicate with Twitter bullshit.

If you wanted to get all pretty about it, you could say that that ethos of "do only what needs to be done, and do it well" mirrors the singularity of purpose of F1, and a sort of purity that underlies all competitive sport.

Or... you know, maybe guys just like when cars go "vroom".

reviews.content: Being an American I grew up watching CART (open wheel) racing at the Cleveland GP.  Then I moved and living in the Southern US, I feel that line about NASCAR hit the nail on the head.  I went to a race in college (Talladega), it was like watching adult bumper cars at 175 mph.  The camping area was the real show, wow!  Anyhow, I'm an F1 fan now, I live close enough to go to the US GP in Texas, but the last time I priced tickets they were insanely high for anything decent.  It's definitely a high end spectator sport, and the average American will just turn their nose up at it, the price and the recent xenophobia that seems to be surfacing lately will keep folks skeptical of the brand, I hope I am wrong.  The new Cadillac team might do well, but I know better, and really, Cadillac racing???  It's a luxury car company for crying out loud, you can't buy a decent sports car from them.  You want a brand to race: bring back Pontiac, or just Chevy. But, with their participation in Indy I doubt GM would want the brand overlap.  So we get Cadillac for the WEC, IMSA and now F1 ...ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

A young man(Tom Holland) works in a garage in lower Manhattan, his father is the owner, they are both great mechanics and are always in competitions with each other, like who can fix certain car problems the fastest, the garage is having money troubles, Tom wants a quiet life so he plans to one day move to a smaller quieter town and open his own garage, one day while the whole team except for Tom are out for lunch a girl in a sports car goes to the garage as the car just broke down, Tom being the only one there fixes the car for her, she offers a crazy idea, she works with a racing team and says they are needing a mechanic, Tom takes the job as to help with the money for his father's garage. reviews.content: Knock NASCAR all you want, Scotsman, but first of all it follows the format of the Roman chariot race -Ben Hur with blades around an oval, death to the competitors in front of thousands of screaming fans. It's the restart rule that puts the cars together to force wheel to wheel racing which you never ever get in F1. When Juan Pablo Montoya drove in NASCAR, he said it was the most challenging series he's driven in. He was not wrong. Having dozens of other cars only inches or feet away at nearly 200mph is a major challenge for any driver. See, F1 focused on the ultimate car, NASCAR focused on the ultimate race. We want to watch the dogfight play out, not watch cars which could be qualifying or maybe racing and who can tell the difference anyway zooming along once every few minutes with no idea who is in front if we didn't have a leaderboard. NASCAR is a gladiatorial spectacle. Or at least it used to be before it became tamed and PC and tried to cater to "modern audiences" in it's own way. The other beautiful thing about it was that back in the day, a middle class small business owner could field a team. Cars were not that expensive, and they weren't that complex. It was a blue collar sport for working class people. Surely you can appreciate that.

reviews.content: Saw the movie last night.  It was...okay.  The visuals were very good, especially the flashback driving footage.  The sound was good too.  Some of the acting was excellent.  The script, however, was a little clunky. There was a lot of pandering, which I assume was meant to target the Drive to Survive F1 "fans."  The movie dumbed down F1, as Casino Royale dumbed down bluffing.  I did take issue with the fact that they tried so hard, and too obtusely, to represent women and black people.  It was too obvious, and didn't add to the story.  This saddened me.

reviews.content: You can tell that F1 was heavily edited even with the huge runtime.  The story of JP was ineffectual and would have saved a ton of time if it was cut down.  The audience is told that he is a great driver but never really shown examples of his potential or even given that much of an arc.  What was shown on screen is a driver that wrecked like three or four cars in less than one season without finishing first.  No team would hire him as a driver after that performance.  F1 was ok, it kind of felt like it was hampered by producers that didn't want to focus on Sonny's story.  So, instead we tried to have a two stories slammed together.  Imagine something like Days of Thunder focusing on Russ Wheeler's story as well, it would have felt bloated.

reviews.content:
This is the plot  - with all the spoilers. 
Old, experienced white man with few resources but not seeking to enrich himself despite all his natural advantages,  helps a young, brash, rich, self-important black man. The young black man  never stops complaining about the old white man. Despite this, the old white man does everything he can, including sacrificing his own races, to make the black man win. Because the black man is so contemptuous of the old white man,  he sabotages the white man's efforts to help the young black man win. The young black man openly rejects the help and advice of the white man, and when that rejection of advice leads directly in the black man crashing, and nearly dying,  it's the old white man that is blamed and forced to take the emotional burden of being at fault. The movie climaxes at a point where finally, all the white people in the movie put a race win right into the young black man's lap, when another black man (lewis hamilton) takes him out and the old white man has to win the race himself. Old white man ends the movie, not with fame and fortune, despite him saving the day at every turn, but goes on to the next charity race team, this time brown people, to selfless help. The young black man takes the fame and fortune made possible by the old white man and isn't seen helping anyone.
It might be a more accurate social commentary that most people realise.

Then there‚Äôs this üá∫üá∏, the last American to win in F1 was Mario Andretti in 1978, coincidentally the last year an American won the World championship. It's one of those fine films that transcends being a movie and becomes an experience.   A lot of car p_rn ... but damn those are sexy machines. reviews.content: I'm going to be that guy and say it was a meh movie. We've been so deprived of good media that it seems like it was great in comparison. As an F1 and movie fan, I found it quite boring. Visually striking but movie style editing doesn't suit this kind of racing. I'd much rather have used that time to watch an actual race. I also get that the screenwriters had to add in dialogue that simplifies what's going on but it seems overtly simplistic to someone who knows. It's like a commentator in football going 'this team needs to kick the ball because when they hit it into the net, it means they have scored a goal and the team with the most goals at the end of 90 minutes wins. As far as the story? Same old Hollywood cliches and tropes we've been seeing since time immemorial, honestly they're all like caricatures and not a single character managed to make me think they're a real person. Nothing the characters do makes any sense given what we're told about them because they flip their personalities constantly. It all seemed so contrived. So in short it's a visually fantastic movie for non F1 fans who want a familiar and uncomplicated story. Only good thing in my opinion is that they really did a good job showcasing F1 as a sport and how it works which might create new F1 fans

Want to see the insides of F1? See "Senna".

reviews.content: Well, a surprise invitation from an old friend found me in a theatre this morning for the 10:50 am screening of "F1."  It is even worse than I imagined. Pure crap. Piles of crap. Tons of crap. The credits explain it all...produced by Jerry Bruckheimer (who gave us "Days of Thunder" and "Top Gun)...a producer noted for his excesses of bad taste. The funniest part of the movie is the list of other "producers" who also appear in the movie as themselves. This cinematic garbage bears no resemblance to auto racing...of any kind. It is a cartoon, a live action fairy tale straight from a freshman screen writing class by Ted Field. The music score by Hans Zimmer doesn't even qualify as music. He must have been high on ED medication when he sat down at his synthesizer. There is not a single intelligent moment in "F1."
